Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Each time you take a step, 200 muscles work in unison
to lift your foot, propel it forward, and set it down. It's just one of the many thousands
of tasks performed by the muscular system. This network of over 650 muscles
covers the body and is the reason we can blink, smile, run, jump, and stand upright. It's even responsible for 
the heart's dependable thump. First, what exactly 
is the muscular system? It's made up of three main muscle types: skeletal muscle, which attaches
via tendons to our bones, cardiac muscle, which is only
found in the heart, and smooth muscle, which lines
the blood vessels and certain organs, like the intestine and uterus. All three types are 
made up of muscle cells, also known as fibers,
bundled tightly together. These bundles receive signals from
the nervous system that contract the fibers, which in turn
generates force and motion. This produces almost all
the movements we make. Some of the only parts of the body whose motions aren't governed 
by the muscular system are sperm cells, the hair-like cilia in our airways, and certain white blood cells. Muscle contraction can be split
into three main types. The first two, shortening muscle fibers
and lengthening them, generate opposing forces. So the biceps will shorten
while the triceps will lengthen or relax, pulling up the arm and making it 
bend at the elbow. This allows us to, say, pick up a book, or if the muscle relationship 
is reversed, put it down. This complementary partnership
exists throughout the muscular system. The third type of contraction
creates a stabilizing force. In these cases, the muscle fibers
don't change in length, but instead keep the muscles rigid. This allows us to grip a mug of coffee
or lean against a wall. It also maintains our posture
by holding us upright. Skeletal muscles form the bulk
of the muscular system, make up about 30-40% of the body's weight, and generate most of its motion. Some muscles are familiar to us,
like the pectorals and the biceps. Others may be less so,
like the buccinator, a muscle that attaches your cheek
to your teeth, or the body's tiniest skeletal muscle, a one-millimeter-long tissue fragment
called the stapedius that's nestled deep inside the ear. Wherever they occur, skeletal muscles are
connected to the somatic nervous system, which gives us almost complete control
over their movements. This muscle group also contains
two types of muscle fibers to refine our motions even further,
slow-twitch and fast-twitch. Fast-twitch fibers react instantly
when triggered but quickly use up their energy
and tire out. Slow-twitch fibers, on the other hand,
are endurance cells. They react and use energy slowly
so they can work for longer periods. A sprinter will accumulate more
fast-twitch muscles in her legs through continuous practice, enabling her to quickly, if briefly,
pick up the pace, whereas back muscles contain 
more slow-twitch muscles to maintain your posture all day. Unlike the skeletal muscles, the body's
cardiac and smooth muscles are managed by 
the autonomic nervous system beyond our direct control. That makes your heart thump
roughly 3 billion times over the course of your life, which supplies the body 
with blood and oxygen. Autonomic control also contracts
and relaxes smooth muscle in a rhythmic cycle. That pumps blood through the smooth
internal walls of blood vessels, enables the intestine to constrict and
push food through the digestive system, and allows the uterus to contract
when a person is giving birth. As muscles work, they also use energy
and produce an important byproduct, heat. In fact, muscle provides 
about 85% of your warmth, which the heart and blood vessels
then spread evenly across the body via the blood. Without that, we couldn't maintain
the temperature necessary for our survival. The muscular system 
may be largely invisible to us, but it leaves its mark on almost
everything we do, whether it's the blink of an eye
or a race to the finish line.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What type of muscle makes up the muscular system?
Options: A. Skeletal muscle, B. Cardiac muscle, C. Smooth muscle, D. Skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscle
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How many muscles work together to perform a single step? Options: A. 100 muscles, B. 200 muscles, C. 500 muscles, D. 1000 muscles Correct Option: None
Question 2: What are the three main types of muscles in the muscular system? Options: A. Skeletal, cardiac, and nervous muscles, B. Skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscles, C. Cardiac, smooth, and nervous muscles, D. Skeletal, smooth, and nervous muscles Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the primary function of the skeletal muscles in the muscular system? Options: A. To control the heart rate, B. To regulate digestion, C. To generate most of the body's motion, D. To maintain posture Correct Option: None
Question 4: What type of muscle contraction allows us to grip a mug of coffee or lean against a wall? Options: A. Shortening muscle fibers, B. Lengthening muscle fibers, C. Stabilizing force contraction, D. Fast-twitch muscle contraction Correct Option: None
Question 5: What percentage of the body's weight is made up of skeletal muscles? Options: A. 10-20%, B. 20-30%, C. 30-40%, D. 40-50% Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the name of the muscle that attaches the cheek to the teeth? Options: A. Pectoral muscle, B. Biceps muscle, C. Buccinator muscle, D. Stapedius muscle Correct Option: None
Question 7: What type of nervous system controls the skeletal muscles? Options: A. Autonomic nervous system, B. Somatic nervous system, C. Central nervous system, D. Peripheral nervous system Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the primary function of fast-twitch muscle fibers? Options: A. To provide endurance, B. To react quickly and generate instant force, C. To maintain posture, D. To regulate digestion Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the estimated number of times the heart beats in a person's lifetime? Options: A. 1 billion times, B. 2 billion times, C. 3 billion times, D. 4 billion times Correct Option: None
Question 10: What percentage of the body's warmth is provided by muscle activity? Options: A. 50%, B. 60%, C. 75%, D. 85% Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: What are the three main types of muscles in the muscular system? Options: A. Skeletal, cardiac, and nervous muscles, B. Skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscles, C. Cardiac, smooth, and nervous muscles, D. Skeletal, smooth, and nervous muscles.

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The ground truth MCQ asks about the type of muscle that makes up the muscular system, and the correct option is D. Skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscle. Similarly, Question 2 asks about the three main types of muscles in the muscular system, and option B lists the correct types of muscles.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Each time you take a step, 200 muscles work in unison
to lift your foot, propel it forward, and set it down. It's just one of the many thousands
of tasks performed by the muscular system. This network of over 650 muscles
covers the body and is the reason we can blink, smile, run, jump, and stand upright. It's even responsible for 
the heart's dependable thump. First, what exactly 
is the muscular system? It's made up of three main muscle types: skeletal muscle, which attaches
via tendons to our bones, cardiac muscle, which is only
found in the heart, and smooth muscle, which lines
the blood vessels and certain organs, like the intestine and uterus. All three types are 
made up of muscle cells, also known as fibers,
bundled tightly together. These bundles receive signals from
the nervous system that contract the fibers, which in turn
generates force and motion. This produces almost all
the movements we make. Some of the only parts of the body whose motions aren't governed

into three main types. The first two, shortening muscle fibers
and lengthening them, generate opposing forces. So the biceps will shorten

creates a stabilizing force. In these cases, the muscle fibers

or lean against a wall. It also maintains our posture
by holding us upright. Skeletal muscles form the bulk
of the muscular system, make up about 30-40% of the body's weight, and generate most of its motion. Some muscles are familiar to us,
like the pectorals and the biceps. Others may be less so,
like the buccinator, a muscle that attaches your cheek
to your teeth, or the body's tiniest skeletal muscle, a one-millimeter-long tissue fragment
called the stapedius that's nestled deep inside the ear. Wherever they occur, skeletal muscles are

over their movements. This muscle group also contains
two types of muscle fibers to refine our motions even further,
slow-twitch and fast-twitch. Fast-twitch fibers react instantly
when triggered but quickly use up their energy
and tire out. Slow-twitch fibers, on the other hand,
are endurance cells. They react and use energy slowly
so they can work for longer periods. A sprinter will accumulate more
fast-twitch muscles in her legs through continuous practice, enabling her to quickly, if briefly,
pick up the pace, whereas back muscles contain 
more slow-twitch muscles to maintain your posture all day. Unlike the skeletal muscles, the body's
cardiac and smooth muscles are managed by 
the autonomic nervous system beyond our direct control. That makes your heart thump
roughly 3 billion times over the course of your life, which supplies the body 
with blood and oxygen. Autonomic control also contracts
and relaxes smooth muscle in a rhythmic cycle. That pumps blood through the smooth
internal walls of blood vessels, enables the intestine to constrict and
push food through the digestive system, and allows the uterus to contract
when a person is giving birth. As muscles work, they also use energy
and produce an important byproduct, heat. In fact, muscle provides 
about 85% of your warmth, which the heart and blood vessels
then spread evenly across the body via the blood. Without that, we couldn't maintain
the temperature necessary for our survival. The muscular system 
may be largely invisible to us, but it leaves its mark on almost
everything we do, whether it's the blink of an eye
or a race to the finish line.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Fast twitch muscle cells:
Options: A. Use energy slowly, B. Would be abundant in the muscles of a sprinter, C. Have lots of nerve cells, D. Help us to stand upright
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

This question is about the primary function of fast-twitch muscle fibers, which aligns with the ground truth MCQ's focus on the characteristics of fast-twitch muscle cells. The correct option for Question 8, "To react quickly and generate instant force," is similar to the correct option for the ground truth MCQ, which states that fast-twitch muscle cells "Would be abundant in the muscles of a sprinter." Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: One type of muscle contraction results in a stabilizing force. This:
Options: A. Enables us to stand and sit upright, B. Means it helps us to lift heavy things, C. Makes the muscle very tense
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. with blood and oxygen. Autonomic control also contracts
and relaxes smooth muscle in a rhythmic cycle. That pumps blood through the smooth
internal walls of blood vessels, enables the intestine to constrict and
push food through the digestive system, and allows the uterus to contract
when a person is giving birth. As muscles work, they also use energy
and produce an important byproduct, heat. In fact, muscle provides 
about 85% of your warmth, which the heart and blood vessels
then spread evenly across the body via the blood. Without that, we couldn't maintain
the temperature necessary for our survival. The muscular system 
may be largely invisible to us, but it leaves its mark on almost
everything we do, whether it's the blink of an eye
or a race to the finish line.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Without the muscular system, we wouldn’t be able to make most of the body heat that we require.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How many muscles work together to perform a single step? Options: A. 100 muscles, B. 200 muscles, C. 500 muscles, D. 1000 muscles Correct Option: None
Question 2: What are the three main types of muscles in the muscular system? Options: A. Skeletal, cardiac, and nervous muscles, B. Skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscles, C. Cardiac, smooth, and nervous muscles, D. Skeletal, smooth, and nervous muscles Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the primary function of the skeletal muscles in the muscular system? Options: A. To control the heart rate, B. To regulate digestion, C. To generate most of the body's motion, D. To maintain posture Correct Option: None
Question 4: What type of muscle contraction allows us to grip a mug of coffee or lean against a wall? Options: A. Shortening muscle fibers, B. Lengthening muscle fibers, C. Stabilizing force contraction, D. Fast-twitch muscle contraction Correct Option: None
Question 5: What percentage of the body's weight is made up of skeletal muscles? Options: A. 10-20%, B. 20-30%, C. 30-40%, D. 40-50% Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the name of the muscle that attaches the cheek to the teeth? Options: A. Pectoral muscle, B. Biceps muscle, C. Buccinator muscle, D. Stapedius muscle Correct Option: None
Question 7: What type of nervous system controls the skeletal muscles? Options: A. Autonomic nervous system, B. Somatic nervous system, C. Central nervous system, D. Peripheral nervous system Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the primary function of fast-twitch muscle fibers? Options: A. To provide endurance, B. To react quickly and generate instant force, C. To maintain posture, D. To regulate digestion Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the estimated number of times the heart beats in a person's lifetime? Options: A. 1 billion times, B. 2 billion times, C. 3 billion times, D. 4 billion times Correct Option: None
Question 10: What percentage of the body's warmth is provided by muscle activity? Options: A. 50%, B. 60%, C. 75%, D. 85% Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 10.

The correct option for Question 10 is D. 85%, which aligns with the information provided in the transcript. The ground truth MCQ states that without the muscular system, we wouldn't be able to make most of the body heat that we require, and the transcript mentions that muscle provides about 85% of our warmth.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the 1950s, a group of ranchers in Idaho were baffled when their sheep gave birth
to lambs with a singular deformity. Mystified by these cyclops sheep, they called in scientists from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture to investigate. The researchers hypothesized
that the pregnant ewes had snacked on poisonous 
birth defect-causing plants. They collected the local flora
and fed samples to lab rats, but struggled to replicate the effect. So they decided 
to directly observe the sheep with one scientist even living
with the herd for three summers. After a decade of trial and error,
the scientists finally found the culprit, wild corn lilies. The lilies contained an active molecule
with six connected rings that they named cyclopamine
in reference to the cyclops sheep. They didn't know exactly
how cyclopamine caused the defect but told ranchers to steer clear. It took about four decades before
a team of biologists, led by Professor Philip Beachy, stumbled upon the answer. His lab was studying a specific gene
found in many species, from mice to humans, called the hedgehog gene. It was named by two scientists, who later
shared the Noble Prize for their work, who found that mutating 
this gene in fruit flies produced pointy spikes like a hedgehog. Beachy and his colleagues performed
genetic modifications to turn off the hedgehog genes in mice. This resulted in severe defects 
in the development of their brains, organs, and eyes or, rather, eye. Then while perusing a textbook, Beachy 
came across photos of the cyclops sheep and realized what had eluded scientists
for four decades. Something must have gone awry 
involving the hedgehog gene. Let's take a step back. Genes contain instructions that tell
cells what to do and when to do it, and they communicate their directives
using proteins. The hedgehog gene itself tells cells
to release a so-called hedgehog protein, which kicks off a complex 
series of cellular signals. Here's how it works in normal
healthy development. Hedgehog protein latches on to
a protein called patched. That inhibits, or holds, patched back, allowing another protein called
smoothened to freely signal the cells, telling them where to go
and what kind of tissues to become. Cyclopamine, say in the form 
of a delicious corn lily, interrupts this pathway
by binding onto smoothened. That locks smoothened up so that
it's unable to send the signals needed to mold the brain 
into two hemispheres, and form fingers or separate eyes. So even though the hedgehog
protein is still doing its job of keeping the way clear for smoothened, cyclopamine blocks smoothened
from passing along its chemical message. That settled the science
behind the one-eyed sheep, but Beachy and his team 
caught the glimmer of another more beneficial connection. They noted that uncontrolled activation
of the smoothened protein was associated with a human syndrome. It's known as Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome,
and it predisposes people to certain cancers. The scientists proposed putting cyclopamine's smoothened 
binding powers to good use as a treatment for these cancers, as long as the patient wasn't pregnant. Unfortunately, researchers eventually
found that cyclopamine causes negative side effects, and its chemical properties
make it difficult to work with. But they did discover that closely
related molecules are safe and effective, and two of these drugs were approved
in 2012 and 2015 as skin cancer medicines. When those farmers first saw
the cyclops sheep, they could have chalked it up to
a freak genetic mutation and walked away. Instead, their decision to investigate
turned a mystery into medicine showing that sometimes
there's more than meets the eye.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Scientists discovered that the cyclops sheep deformity was caused by pregnant ewes eating:
Options: A. Grass, B. Berries, C. Wild corn lilies, D. Fruit flies
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the deformity observed in the lambs born to sheep in Idaho in the 1950s? Options: A. Blindness, B. Extra limbs, C. A singular eye (cyclops), D. Deformed ears Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the initial hypothesis of the researchers regarding the cause of the deformity in the sheep? Options: A. Genetic mutation, B. Poisonous plants, C. Environmental factors, D. Infections Correct Option: None
Question 3: What was the name given to the active molecule found in the wild corn lilies that caused the deformity? Options: A. Cyclopamine, B. Hedgehog protein, C. Smoothened protein, D. Patched protein Correct Option: None
Question 4: Who led the team of biologists that discovered the connection between cyclopamine and the hedgehog gene? Options: A. Professor Philip Beachy, B. Dr. James Watson, C. Dr. Francis Crick, D. Dr. Charles Darwin Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the function of the hedgehog gene in normal development? Options: A. To regulate cell growth, B. To control cell division, C. To tell cells to release the hedgehog protein, D. To regulate metabolism Correct Option: None
Question 6: How does cyclopamine interrupt the normal development pathway? Options: A. By binding to the hedgehog protein, B. By inhibiting the patched protein, C. By binding to the smoothened protein, D. By activating the patched protein Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the human syndrome associated with uncontrolled activation of the smoothened protein? Options: A. Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome, B. Cyclopamine Syndrome, C. Hedgehog Syndrome, D. Smoothened Syndrome Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why was cyclopamine not used as a treatment for cancers despite its potential? Options: A. It was not effective, B. It caused negative side effects, C. It was too expensive, D. It was not approved by the FDA Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the outcome of the research on cyclopamine and its related molecules? Options: A. No effective treatments were found, B. Two related molecules were approved as skin cancer medicines, C. Cyclopamine was approved as a treatment for cancers, D. The research was discontinued Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main lesson from the story of the cyclops sheep? Options: A. That genetic mutations are always freak occurrences, B. That sometimes there's more than meets the eye, C. That scientists should never investigate unusual occurrences, D. That all deformities are caused by environmental factors Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 3: What was the name given to the active molecule found in the wild corn lilies that caused the deformity?**

However, the options provided in this question do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ. A more suitable match in terms of question intent and content would be a generated MCQ that directly asks about the cause of the deformity and includes "wild corn lilies" as an option.

Unfortunately, none of the provided generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of both question intent and options. But if I had to choose the closest match based on content, I would suggest:

However, this question does not have the correct options to match the ground truth MCQ.

Options: A. Grass, B. Berries, C. Wild corn lilies, D. Fruit flies

Since this is not an option, I will choose the closest match based on content, which is:

with six connected rings that they named cyclopamine

a team of biologists, led by Professor Philip Beachy, stumbled upon the answer. His lab was studying a specific gene
found in many species, from mice to humans, called the hedgehog gene. It was named by two scientists, who later
shared the Noble Prize for their work, who found that mutating 
this gene in fruit flies produced pointy spikes like a hedgehog. Beachy and his colleagues performed

turned a mystery into medicine showing that sometimes
there's more than meets the eye.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Two scientists won the Nobel Prize for the discovery of the hedgehog gene. Why did they choose that name?
Options: A. The gene is only found in hedgehogs, B. Mutations in the gene caused spikes like a hedgehog to form on fruit flies’ bodies, C. Mutations in the gene caused spikes like a hedgehog to form on mice, D. The gene was first discovered in hedgehogs
Correct Option: B

Question 6: How does cyclopamine interrupt the normal development pathway? Options: A. By binding to the hedgehog protein, B. By inhibiting the patched protein, C. By binding to the smoothened protein, D. By activating the patched protein Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the human syndrome associated with uncontrolled activation of the smoothened protein? Options: A. Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome, B. Cyclopamine Syndrome, C. Hedgehog Syndrome, D. Smoothened Syndrome Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why was cyclopamine not used as a treatment for cancers despite its potential? Options: A. It was not effective, B. It caused negative side effects, C. It was too expensive, D. It was not approved by the FDA Correct Option: None

Two related molecules were approved as skin cancer medicines, C. Cyclopamine was approved as a treatment for cancers, D. The research was discontinued Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main lesson from the story of the cyclops sheep? Options: A. That genetic mutations are always freak occurrences, B. That sometimes there's more than meets the eye, C. That scientists should never investigate unusual occurrences, D. That all deformities are caused by environmental factors Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

Question 6: How does cyclopamine interrupt the normal development pathway? Options: A. By binding to the hedgehog protein, B. By inhibiting the patched protein, C. By binding to the smoothened protein, D. By activating the patched protein

However, this question does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about how cyclopamine interrupts the pathway, whereas the ground truth MCQ asks about the protein that the hedgehog protein latches onto in healthy cells.

A more similar question would be one that asks about the interaction between the hedgehog protein and other proteins in the pathway. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the 1950s, a group of ranchers in Idaho were baffled when their sheep gave birth
to lambs with a singular deformity. Mystified by these cyclops sheep, they called in scientists from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture to investigate. The researchers hypothesized
that the pregnant ewes had snacked on poisonous 
birth defect-causing plants. They collected the local flora
and fed samples to lab rats, but struggled to replicate the effect. So they decided 
to directly observe the sheep with one scientist even living
with the herd for three summers. After a decade of trial and error,
the scientists finally found the culprit, wild corn lilies. The lilies contained an active molecule
with six connected rings that they named cyclopamine
in reference to the cyclops sheep. They didn't know exactly
how cyclopamine caused the defect but told ranchers to steer clear. It took about four decades before
a team of biologists, led by Professor Philip Beachy, stumbled upon the answer. His lab was studying a specific gene
found in many species, from mice to humans, called the hedgehog gene. It was named by two scientists, who later
shared the Noble Prize for their work, who found that mutating 
this gene in fruit flies produced pointy spikes like a hedgehog. Beachy and his colleagues performed
genetic modifications to turn off the hedgehog genes in mice. This resulted in severe defects 
in the development of their brains, organs, and eyes or, rather, eye. Then while perusing a textbook, Beachy 
came across photos of the cyclops sheep and realized what had eluded scientists
for four decades. Something must have gone awry 
involving the hedgehog gene. Let's take a step back. Genes contain instructions that tell
cells what to do and when to do it, and they communicate their directives
using proteins. The hedgehog gene itself tells cells
to release a so-called hedgehog protein, which kicks off a complex 
series of cellular signals. Here's how it works in normal
healthy development. Hedgehog protein latches on to
a protein called patched. That inhibits, or holds, patched back, allowing another protein called
smoothened to freely signal the cells, telling them where to go
and what kind of tissues to become. Cyclopamine, say in the form 
of a delicious corn lily, interrupts this pathway
by binding onto smoothened. That locks smoothened up so that
it's unable to send the signals needed to mold the brain 
into two hemispheres, and form fingers or separate eyes. So even though the hedgehog
protein is still doing its job of keeping the way clear for smoothened, cyclopamine blocks smoothened
from passing along its chemical message. That settled the science
behind the one-eyed sheep, but Beachy and his team 
caught the glimmer of another more beneficial connection. They noted that uncontrolled activation
of the smoothened protein was associated with a human syndrome. It's known as Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome,
and it predisposes people to certain cancers. The scientists proposed putting cyclopamine's smoothened 
binding powers to good use as a treatment for these cancers, as long as the patient wasn't pregnant. Unfortunately, researchers eventually
found that cyclopamine causes negative side effects, and its chemical properties
make it difficult to work with. But they did discover that closely
related molecules are safe and effective, and two of these drugs were approved
in 2012 and 2015 as skin cancer medicines. When those farmers first saw
the cyclops sheep, they could have chalked it up to
a freak genetic mutation and walked away. Instead, their decision to investigate
turned a mystery into medicine showing that sometimes
there's more than meets the eye.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Scientists discovered that compounds related to cyclopamine could be used to treat what kind of cancer?
Options: A. Lung cancer, B. Brain cancer, C. Colon cancer, D. Skin cancer
Correct Option: D

Question 4: Who led the team of biologists that discovered the connection between cyclopamine and the hedgehog gene? Options: A. Professor Philip Beachy, B. Dr. James Watson, C. Dr. Francis Crick, D. Dr. Charles Darwin Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the function of the hedgehog gene in normal development? Options: A. To regulate cell growth, B. To control cell division, C. To tell cells to release the hedgehog protein, D. To regulate metabolism Correct Option: None
Question 6: How does cyclopamine interrupt the normal development pathway? Options: A. By binding to the hedgehog protein, B. By inhibiting the patched protein, C. By binding to the smoothened protein, D. By activating the patched protein Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the name of the human syndrome associated with uncontrolled activation of the smoothened protein? Options: A. Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome, B. Cyclopamine Syndrome, C. Hedgehog Syndrome, D. Smoothened Syndrome Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why was cyclopamine not used as a treatment for cancers despite its potential? Options: A. It was not effective, B. It caused negative side effects, C. It was too expensive, D. It was not approved by the FDA Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the outcome of the research on cyclopamine and its related molecules? Options: A. No effective treatments were found, B. Two related molecules were approved as skin cancer medicines, C. Cyclopamine was approved as a treatment for cancers, D. The research was discontinued Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the main lesson from the story of the cyclops sheep? Options: A. That genetic mutations are always freak occurrences, B. That sometimes there's more than meets the eye, C. That scientists should never investigate unusual occurrences, D. That all deformities are caused by environmental factors Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
They say the pen is mightier 
than the sword, and authorities have often agreed. From outlawed religious tracts
and revolutionary manifestos to censored and burned books, we know the potential power
of words to overturn the social order. But as strange as it may seem, some numbers have also been considered
dangerous enough to ban. Our distant ancestors long counted
objects using simple tally marks. But as they developed agriculture and
began living together in larger groups, this was no longer enough. As numbers grew more complex, people began not just using them,
but thinking about what they are and how they work. And by 600 B.C.E. in Ancient Greece,
the study of numbers was well-developed. The mathematician Pythagoras
and his school of followers found numerical patterns in shapes,
music, and the stars. For them, mathematics held 
the deepest secrets of the universe. But one Pythagorean named Hippasus
discovered something disturbing. Some quantities, like the diagonal
of a square with sides of length one couldn't be expressed by any combination
of whole numbers or fractions, no matter how small. These numbers, 
which we call irrational numbers, were perceived as a threat to the Pythagorean's notion 
of a perfect universe. They imagined a reality 
that could be described with rational, numerical patterns. Historians write that Hippasus
was exhiled for publicizing his findings, while legends claim he was drowned
as punishment from the gods. While irrational numbers 
upset philosophers, later mathematical inventions
would draw attention from political 
and religious authorities, as well. In the Middle Ages, while Europe
was still using Roman numerals, other cultures had developed 
positional systems that included a symbol for zero. When Arab travelers brought this system
to the bustling maritime cities of Italy, its advantages for merchants
and bankers was clear. But the authorities were more wary. Hindu-Arabic numerals were considered
easier to forge or alter, especially since they were less
familiar to customers than to merchants. And the concept of zero opened 
the door to negative numbers and the recording of debt at a time when moneylending
was regarded with suspicion. In the 13th century, Florence banned
the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals for record keeping. And though they soon proved
too useful to ignore, controversies over zero 
and negative numbers continued for a long time. Negative numbers 
were dismissed as absurd well into the 19th century. And prominent mathematicians,
like Gerolamo Cardano, avoided using zero, even though it would have made it
much easier to find solutions to cubic and the quartic equations. Even today it's illegal to use
some numbers for different reasons. Some are banned because
of what they represent. For example, governments
have prohibited the display of numbers that have symbolic meaning, such as the date of a revolution or connections to oppositional 
political figures or parties. Other numbers are potentially illegal
because of the information they carry. Just about any information, whether text, image, video, or executable programs can
be translated into a string of numbers. But this means that protected information, whether copyrights, proprietary materials, or state secrets can also be represented as numbers, so possessing or publishing these numbers
may be treated as a criminal offense. This idea gathered attention in 2001 when code that could be used
to decrypt DVDs was widely shared and distributed
in the form of a large prime number. The idea of illegal numbers 
may sound absurd, but like words, written numbers are a way
of expressing concepts and information. And in a world where calculations 
and algorithms shape more and more of our lives, the mathematician's pencil
grows stronger by the day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Our distant ancestors counted objects using:
Options: A. Tally marks, B. Roman numerals, C. Fingers and toes, D. Fractions
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What did ancient people use to count objects before developing more complex number systems? Options: A. Fractions, B. Tally marks, C. Roman numerals, D. Irrational numbers Correct Option: None
Question 2: In Ancient Greece, who developed the study of numbers and found numerical patterns in shapes, music, and the stars? Options: A. Hippasus, B. Pythagoras, C. Gerolamo Cardano, D. Euclid Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of numbers did Hippasus discover, which were perceived as a threat to the Pythagorean's notion of a perfect universe? Options: A. Rational numbers, B. Irrational numbers, C. Whole numbers, D. Negative numbers Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the punishment for Hippasus, according to legends, for publicizing his findings on irrational numbers? Options: A. Exile, B. Drowning, C. Imprisonment, D. Fines Correct Option: None
Question 5: Which mathematical system, developed by other cultures, was introduced to Europe through Arab travelers in the Middle Ages? Options: A. Roman numerals, B. Hindu-Arabic numerals, C. Greek numerals, D. Egyptian numerals Correct Option: None
Question 6: Why were Hindu-Arabic numerals initially banned in Florence in the 13th century? Options: A. They were too complex, B. They were easier to forge or alter, C. They were too difficult to learn, D. They were not useful for merchants Correct Option: None
Question 7: Which prominent mathematician avoided using zero, even though it would have made it easier to find solutions to cubic and quartic equations? Options: A. Pythagoras, B. Hippasus, C. Gerolamo Cardano, D. Euclid Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why are some numbers banned today, according to the transcript? Options: A. Because they are too large, B. Because they are too complex, C. Because of what they represent or the information they carry, D. Because they are too small Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the example given in the transcript of a number that was widely shared and distributed, and was considered a potential criminal offense? Options: A. A large prime number that could be used to decrypt DVDs, B. A code that could be used to hack into computers, C. A password that could be used to access protected information, D. A numerical representation of a copyrighted image Correct Option: None
Question 10: According to the transcript, why is the concept of "illegal numbers" not as absurd as it may seem? Options: A. Because numbers are just abstract concepts, B. Because numbers can be used to represent and convey information, C. Because numbers are only used in mathematics, D. Because numbers are not important in our daily lives Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the correct option is not explicitly marked for the generated MCQs, based on the content and options provided, Question 1 is the closest match to the ground truth MCQ. Both questions ask about the method used by ancient people to count objects, and both have "tally marks" as an option. 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
They say the pen is mightier 
than the sword, and authorities have often agreed. From outlawed religious tracts
and revolutionary manifestos to censored and burned books, we know the potential power
of words to overturn the social order. But as strange as it may seem, some numbers have also been considered
dangerous enough to ban. Our distant ancestors long counted
objects using simple tally marks. But as they developed agriculture and
began living together in larger groups, this was no longer enough. As numbers grew more complex, people began not just using them,
but thinking about what they are and how they work. And by 600 B.C.E. in Ancient Greece,
the study of numbers was well-developed. The mathematician Pythagoras
and his school of followers found numerical patterns in shapes,
music, and the stars. For them, mathematics held 
the deepest secrets of the universe. But one Pythagorean named Hippasus
discovered something disturbing. Some quantities, like the diagonal
of a square with sides of length one couldn't be expressed by any combination
of whole numbers or fractions, no matter how small. These numbers, 
which we call irrational numbers, were perceived as a threat to the Pythagorean's notion 
of a perfect universe. They imagined a reality 
that could be described with rational, numerical patterns. Historians write that Hippasus
was exhiled for publicizing his findings, while legends claim he was drowned
as punishment from the gods. While irrational numbers 
upset philosophers, later mathematical inventions
would draw attention from political 
and religious authorities, as well. In the Middle Ages, while Europe
was still using Roman numerals, other cultures had developed 
positional systems that included a symbol for zero. When Arab travelers brought this system
to the bustling maritime cities of Italy, its advantages for merchants
and bankers was clear. But the authorities were more wary. Hindu-Arabic numerals were considered
easier to forge or alter, especially since they were less
familiar to customers than to merchants. And the concept of zero opened 
the door to negative numbers and the recording of debt at a time when moneylending
was regarded with suspicion. In the 13th century, Florence banned
the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals for record keeping. And though they soon proved
too useful to ignore, controversies over zero 
and negative numbers continued for a long time. Negative numbers 
were dismissed as absurd well into the 19th century. And prominent mathematicians,
like Gerolamo Cardano, avoided using zero, even though it would have made it
much easier to find solutions to cubic and the quartic equations. Even today it's illegal to use
some numbers for different reasons. Some are banned because
of what they represent. For example, governments
have prohibited the display of numbers that have symbolic meaning, such as the date of a revolution or connections to oppositional 
political figures or parties. Other numbers are potentially illegal
because of the information they carry. Just about any information, whether text, image, video, or executable programs can
be translated into a string of numbers. But this means that protected information, whether copyrights, proprietary materials, or state secrets can also be represented as numbers, so possessing or publishing these numbers
may be treated as a criminal offense. This idea gathered attention in 2001 when code that could be used
to decrypt DVDs was widely shared and distributed
in the form of a large prime number. The idea of illegal numbers 
may sound absurd, but like words, written numbers are a way
of expressing concepts and information. And in a world where calculations 
and algorithms shape more and more of our lives, the mathematician's pencil
grows stronger by the day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why were Arabic numerals banned for record-keeping in Florence?
Options: A. Because they were unfamiliar to most people, B. Because they were not useful, C. Because they were illegible, D. Because they were regarded as easy to adjust fraudulently
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What did ancient people use to count objects before developing more complex number systems? Options: A. Fractions, B. Tally marks, C. Roman numerals, D. Irrational numbers Correct Option: None
Question 2: In Ancient Greece, who developed the study of numbers and found numerical patterns in shapes, music, and the stars? Options: A. Hippasus, B. Pythagoras, C. Gerolamo Cardano, D. Euclid Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of numbers did Hippasus discover, which were perceived as a threat to the Pythagorean's notion of a perfect universe? Options: A. Rational numbers, B. Irrational numbers, C. Whole numbers, D. Negative numbers Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the punishment for Hippasus, according to legends, for publicizing his findings on irrational numbers? Options: A. Exile, B. Drowning, C. Imprisonment, D. Fines Correct Option: None
Question 5: Which mathematical system, developed by other cultures, was introduced to Europe through Arab travelers in the Middle Ages? Options: A. Roman numerals, B. Hindu-Arabic numerals, C. Greek numerals, D. Egyptian numerals Correct Option: None
Question 6: Why were Hindu-Arabic numerals initially banned in Florence in the 13th century? Options: A. They were too complex, B. They were easier to forge or alter, C. They were too difficult to learn, D. They were not useful for merchants Correct Option: None
Question 7: Which prominent mathematician avoided using zero, even though it would have made it easier to find solutions to cubic and quartic equations? Options: A. Pythagoras, B. Hippasus, C. Gerolamo Cardano, D. Euclid Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why are some numbers banned today, according to the transcript? Options: A. Because they are too large, B. Because they are too complex, C. Because of what they represent or the information they carry, D. Because they are too small Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the example given in the transcript of a number that was widely shared and distributed, and was considered a potential criminal offense? Options: A. A large prime number that could be used to decrypt DVDs, B. A code that could be used to hack into computers, C. A password that could be used to access protected information, D. A numerical representation of a copyrighted image Correct Option: None
Question 10: According to the transcript, why is the concept of "illegal numbers" not as absurd as it may seem? Options: A. Because numbers are just abstract concepts, B. Because numbers can be used to represent and convey information, C. Because numbers are only used in mathematics, D. Because numbers are not important in our daily lives Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to ask why Hindu-Arabic numerals were banned in Florence. The correct option for Question 6, "They were easier to forge or alter," is also the same as the correct option for the ground truth MCQ, "Because they were regarded as easy to adjust fraudulently." Although the wording is slightly different, the meaning is the same.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 6.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
They say the pen is mightier 
than the sword, and authorities have often agreed. From outlawed religious tracts
and revolutionary manifestos to censored and burned books, we know the potential power
of words to overturn the social order. But as strange as it may seem, some numbers have also been considered
dangerous enough to ban. Our distant ancestors long counted
objects using simple tally marks. But as they developed agriculture and
began living together in larger groups, this was no longer enough. As numbers grew more complex, people began not just using them,
but thinking about what they are and how they work. And by 600 B.C.E. in Ancient Greece,
the study of numbers was well-developed. The mathematician Pythagoras
and his school of followers found numerical patterns in shapes,
music, and the stars. For them, mathematics held 
the deepest secrets of the universe. But one Pythagorean named Hippasus
discovered something disturbing. Some quantities, like the diagonal
of a square with sides of length one couldn't be expressed by any combination
of whole numbers or fractions, no matter how small. These numbers, 
which we call irrational numbers, were perceived as a threat to the Pythagorean's notion 
of a perfect universe. They imagined a reality 
that could be described with rational, numerical patterns. Historians write that Hippasus
was exhiled for publicizing his findings, while legends claim he was drowned
as punishment from the gods. While irrational numbers 
upset philosophers, later mathematical inventions
would draw attention from political 
and religious authorities, as well. In the Middle Ages, while Europe
was still using Roman numerals, other cultures had developed 
positional systems that included a symbol for zero. When Arab travelers brought this system
to the bustling maritime cities of Italy, its advantages for merchants
and bankers was clear. But the authorities were more wary. Hindu-Arabic numerals were considered
easier to forge or alter, especially since they were less
familiar to customers than to merchants. And the concept of zero opened 
the door to negative numbers and the recording of debt at a time when moneylending
was regarded with suspicion. In the 13th century, Florence banned
the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals for record keeping. And though they soon proved
too useful to ignore, controversies over zero 
and negative numbers continued for a long time. Negative numbers 
were dismissed as absurd well into the 19th century. And prominent mathematicians,
like Gerolamo Cardano, avoided using zero, even though it would have made it
much easier to find solutions to cubic and the quartic equations. Even today it's illegal to use
some numbers for different reasons. Some are banned because
of what they represent. For example, governments
have prohibited the display of numbers that have symbolic meaning, such as the date of a revolution or connections to oppositional 
political figures or parties. Other numbers are potentially illegal
because of the information they carry. Just about any information, whether text, image, video, or executable programs can
be translated into a string of numbers. But this means that protected information, whether copyrights, proprietary materials, or state secrets can also be represented as numbers, so possessing or publishing these numbers
may be treated as a criminal offense. This idea gathered attention in 2001 when code that could be used
to decrypt DVDs was widely shared and distributed
in the form of a large prime number. The idea of illegal numbers 
may sound absurd, but like words, written numbers are a way
of expressing concepts and information. And in a world where calculations 
and algorithms shape more and more of our lives, the mathematician's pencil
grows stronger by the day.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why today it is illegal to use some numbers in some countries?
Options: A. Because they may have symbolic meaning, B. Because they carry copyrighted information, C. Because they carry otherwise protected information, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Question 3: What type of numbers did Hippasus discover, which were perceived as a threat to the Pythagorean's notion of a perfect universe? Options: A. Rational numbers, B. Irrational numbers, C. Whole numbers, D. Negative numbers Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Look at your hand. How do you know it's really yours? It seems obvious, unless you've
experienced the rubber hand illusion. In this experiment, a dummy hand is placed
in front of you and your real hand is hidden
behind a screen. Both are simultaneously stroked
with a paint brush. No matter how much you remind yourself
the dummy hand isn't yours, you eventually start to feel like it is, and inevitably flinch
when it's threatened with a knife. That may just be a temporary trick,
but it speaks to a larger truth: our bodies, the physical, 
biological parts of us, and our minds, the thinking,
conscious aspects, have a complicated, tangled relationship. Which one primarily defines you
or your self? Are you a physical body that only
experiences thoughts and emotions as a result of biochemical interactions
in the brain? That would be a body with a mind. Or is there some non-physical part of you
that's pulling the strings but could live outside 
of your biological body? That would be a mind with a body. That takes us to an old question of whether the body 
and mind are two separate things. In a famous thought experiment, 16th-century philosopher 
René Descartes pointed out that even if all our physical sensations
were just a hallucinatory dream, our mind and thoughts 
would still be there. That, for him, was the ultimate proof
of our existence. And it led him to conclude that the conscious mind is something separate
from the material body that forms the core of our identity. The notion of a non-physical consciousness echoes the belief of many religions
in an immaterial soul for which the body is only 
a temporary shell. If we accept this, 
another problem emerges. How can a non-physical mind have
any interaction with the physical body? If the mind has no shape, 
weight, or motion, how can it move your muscles? Or if we assume it can, why can your mind
only move your body and not others? Some thinkers have found creative ways
to get around this dilemma. For example, the French priest 
and philosopher Nicolas Malebranche claimed that when we think about
reaching for a fork, it's actually god who moves our hand. Another priest philosopher 
named George Berkeley concluded that the material world
is an illusion, existing only as mental perceptions. This question of mind versus body
isn't just the domain of philosophers. With the development of psychology
and neuroscience, scientists have weighed in, as well. Many modern scientists reject the idea that there's any distinction 
between the mind and body. Neuroscience suggests that our bodies,
along with their physical senses, are deeply integrated 
with the activity in our brains to form what we call consciousness. From the day we're born, our mental development is formed
through our body's interaction with the external world. Every sight, sound, and touch create
new maps and representations in the brain that eventually become responsible
for regulating our experience of self. And we have other senses,
besides the typical five, such as the sense of balance and a sense of the relative location
of our body parts. The rubber hand illusion,
and similar virtual reality experiments, show that our senses can easily
mislead us in our judgment of self. They also suggest that our bodies
and external sensations are inseparable from 
our subjective consciousness. If this is true, then perhaps Descartes'
experiment was mistaken from the start. After all, if we close our eyes
in a silent room, the feeling of having a body
isn't something we can just imagine away. This question of mind and body
becomes particularly interesting at a time when we're considering
future technologies, such as neural prosthetics
and wearable robots that could become extended parts
of our bodies. Or the slightly more radical idea
of mind uploading, which dangles the possibility 
of immortal life without a body by transferring a human consciousness
into a computer. If the body is deeply mapped
in the brain, then by extending our sense of self
to new wearable devices, our brains may eventually adapt
to a restructured version with new sensory representations. Or perhaps uploading our consciousness
into a computer might not even be possible unless we can also simulate a body
capable of delivering physical sensations. The idea that our bodies are part
of our consciousness and vice versa also isn't new. It's found extensively 
in Buddhist thought, as well as the writings of philosophers
from Heidegger to Aristotle. But for now, we're still left
with the open question of what exactly our self is. Are we a mind equipped with
a physical body as Descartes suggested? Or a complex organism 
that's gained consciousness over millions of years of evolution thanks to a bigger brain and
more neurons than our distant ancestors? Or something else entirely that
no one's yet dreamt up?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the rubber hand illusion, the dummy hand feels like the viewer’s real hand because of the synchronization between two sensory inputs from both hands. What are those two sensory inputs?
Options: A. Touch and sound, B. Touch and vision, C. Vision and pain, D. Vision and proprioception
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main purpose of the rubber hand illusion experiment? Options: A. To demonstrate the importance of physical sensations in our judgment of self., B. To prove the existence of a non-physical consciousness., C. To show how easily our senses can be misled., D. To test the limits of human endurance. Correct Option: None
Question 2: According to René Descartes, what is the ultimate proof of our existence? Options: A. Our physical sensations., B. Our thoughts and consciousness., C. Our emotions and feelings., D. Our physical bodies. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the problem that arises if we accept the notion of a non-physical consciousness? Options: A. How can a non-physical mind have any interaction with the physical body?, B. How can a physical body have any interaction with a non-physical mind?, C. How can we distinguish between a non-physical mind and a physical body?, D. How can we prove the existence of a non-physical consciousness? Correct Option: None
Question 4: Who claimed that when we think about reaching for a fork, it's actually God who moves our hand? Options: A. René Descartes., B. Nicolas Malebranche., C. George Berkeley., D. Aristotle. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the conclusion of many modern scientists regarding the mind-body problem? Options: A. The mind and body are two separate entities., B. The mind and body are deeply integrated and inseparable., C. The mind is a product of the brain, but the body is not., D. The body is a product of the mind, but the brain is not. Correct Option: None
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the role of our senses in forming our experience of self? Options: A. They create new maps and representations in the brain., B. They regulate our emotions and feelings., C. They distinguish between our physical and non-physical aspects., D. They are irrelevant to our experience of self. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the idea behind mind uploading? Options: A. Transferring a human consciousness into a computer to achieve immortal life., B. Uploading our thoughts and memories into a computer to free up space in our brains., C. Creating a virtual reality where we can exist without our physical bodies., D. Developing neural prosthetics to enhance our cognitive abilities. Correct Option: None
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is a possible requirement for mind uploading to be possible? Options: A. Simulating a body capable of delivering physical sensations., B. Creating a computer program that can mimic human emotions., C. Developing a neural network that can replicate human thought patterns., D. Building a robot that can mimic human movements. Correct Option: None
Question 9: Which philosopher suggested that the material world is an illusion, existing only as mental perceptions? Options: A. René Descartes., B. Nicolas Malebranche., C. George Berkeley., D. Aristotle. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the open question that remains at the end of the transcript? Options: A. What is the nature of consciousness?, B. What is the relationship between the mind and body?, C. What is the definition of self?, D. What is the meaning of life? Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, Question 6 is the closest in terms of discussing the role of sensory inputs in forming our experience of self.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: 6

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Sixteenth-century philosopher René Descartes believed that the mind is something separate from the body because:
Options: A. The material world is an illusion existing only as mental perceptions, B. The existence of anything that we perceive from our senses can fundamentally be questioned, C. Even if we assume that our body is an illusion, our thoughts are still there and that is the ultimate proof of our existence, D. God is moving our bodies and God is immaterial
Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:

experienced the rubber hand illusion. In this experiment, a dummy hand is placed
in front of you and your real hand is hidden
behind a screen. Both are simultaneously stroked
with a paint brush. No matter how much you remind yourself
the dummy hand isn't yours, you eventually start to feel like it is, and inevitably flinch
when it's threatened with a knife. That may just be a temporary trick,
but it speaks to a larger truth: our bodies, the physical, 
biological parts of us, and our minds, the thinking,
conscious aspects, have a complicated, tangled relationship. Which one primarily defines you
or your self? Are you a physical body that only
experiences thoughts and emotions as a result of biochemical interactions
in the brain? That would be a body with a mind. Or is there some non-physical part of you
that's pulling the strings but could live outside 
of your biological body? That would be a mind with a body. That takes us to an old question of whether the body 
and mind are two separate things. In a famous thought experiment, 16th-century philosopher 
René Descartes pointed out that even if all our physical sensations
were just a hallucinatory dream, our mind and thoughts 
would still be there. That, for him, was the ultimate proof
of our existence. And it led him to conclude that the conscious mind is something separate
from the material body that forms the core of our identity. The notion of a non-physical consciousness echoes the belief of many religions
in an immaterial soul for which the body is only 
a temporary shell. If we accept this, 
another problem emerges. How can a non-physical mind have
any interaction with the physical body? If the mind has no shape, 
weight, or motion, how can it move your muscles? Or if we assume it can, why can your mind
only move your body and not others? Some thinkers have found creative ways
to get around this dilemma. For example, the French priest 
and philosopher Nicolas Malebranche claimed that when we think about
reaching for a fork, it's actually god who moves our hand. Another priest philosopher 
named George Berkeley concluded that the material world
is an illusion, existing only as mental perceptions. This question of mind versus body
isn't just the domain of philosophers. With the development of psychology
and neuroscience, scientists have weighed in, as well. Many modern scientists reject the idea that there's any distinction 
between the mind and body. Neuroscience suggests that our bodies,
along with their physical senses, are deeply integrated 
with the activity in our brains to form what we call consciousness. From the day we're born, our mental development is formed
through our body's interaction with the external world. Every sight, sound, and touch create
new maps and representations in the brain that eventually become responsible
for regulating our experience of self. And we have other senses,
besides the typical five, such as the sense of balance and a sense of the relative location
of our body parts. The rubber hand illusion,
and similar virtual reality experiments, show that our senses can easily
mislead us in our judgment of self. They also suggest that our bodies
and external sensations are inseparable from 
our subjective consciousness. If this is true, then perhaps Descartes'
experiment was mistaken from the start. After all, if we close our eyes
in a silent room, the feeling of having a body
isn't something we can just imagine away. This question of mind and body
becomes particularly interesting at a time when we're considering
future technologies, such as neural prosthetics
and wearable robots that could become extended parts
of our bodies. Or the slightly more radical idea
of mind uploading, which dangles the possibility 
of immortal life without a body by transferring a human consciousness
into a computer. If the body is deeply mapped
in the brain, then by extending our sense of self
to new wearable devices, our brains may eventually adapt
to a restructured version with new sensory representations. Or perhaps uploading our consciousness
into a computer might not even be possible unless we can also simulate a body
capable of delivering physical sensations. The idea that our bodies are part
of our consciousness and vice versa also isn't new. It's found extensively 
in Buddhist thought, as well as the writings of philosophers
from Heidegger to Aristotle. But for now, we're still left
with the open question of what exactly our self is. Are we a mind equipped with
a physical body as Descartes suggested? Or a complex organism 
that's gained consciousness over millions of years of evolution thanks to a bigger brain and
more neurons than our distant ancestors? Or something else entirely that
no one's yet dreamt up?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What can we learn from rubber hand illusion or other virtual reality experiments?
Options: A. Our senses can easily mislead us in our judgment of self, B. Our bodies are inseparable from our subjective consciousness, C. Our bodies and minds have a complicated tangled relationship, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

To prove the existence of a non-physical consciousness., C. To show how easily our senses can be misled., D. To test the limits of human endurance. Correct Option: None
Question 2: According to René Descartes, what is the ultimate proof of our existence? Options: A. Our physical sensations., B. Our thoughts and consciousness., C. Our emotions and feelings., D. Our physical bodies. Correct Option: None

How can a physical body have any interaction with a non-physical mind?, C. How can we distinguish between a non-physical mind and a physical body?, D. How can we prove the existence of a non-physical consciousness? Correct Option: None

Question 5: What is the conclusion of many modern scientists regarding the mind-body problem? Options: A. The mind and body are two separate entities., B. The mind and body are deeply integrated and inseparable., C. The mind is a product of the brain, but the body is not., D. The body is a product of the mind, but the brain is not. Correct Option: None
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the role of our senses in forming our experience of self? Options: A. They create new maps and representations in the brain., B. They regulate our emotions and feelings., C. They distinguish between our physical and non-physical aspects., D. They are irrelevant to our experience of self. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the idea behind mind uploading? Options: A. Transferring a human consciousness into a computer to achieve immortal life., B. Uploading our thoughts and memories into a computer to free up space in our brains., C. Creating a virtual reality where we can exist without our physical bodies., D. Developing neural prosthetics to enhance our cognitive abilities. Correct Option: None

Creating a computer program that can mimic human emotions., C. Developing a neural network that can replicate human thought patterns., D. Building a robot that can mimic human movements. Correct Option: None

**Transcript**:
Look at your hand. How do you know it's really yours? It seems obvious, unless you've
experienced the rubber hand illusion. In this experiment, a dummy hand is placed
in front of you and your real hand is hidden
behind a screen. Both are simultaneously stroked
with a paint brush. No matter how much you remind yourself
the dummy hand isn't yours, you eventually start to feel like it is, and inevitably flinch
when it's threatened with a knife. That may just be a temporary trick,
but it speaks to a larger truth: our bodies, the physical, 
biological parts of us, and our minds, the thinking,
conscious aspects, have a complicated, tangled relationship. Which one primarily defines you
or your self? Are you a physical body that only
experiences thoughts and emotions as a result of biochemical interactions
in the brain? That would be a body with a mind. Or is there some non-physical part of you
that's pulling the strings but could live outside 
of your biological body? That would be a mind with a body. That takes us to an old question of whether the body 
and mind are two separate things. In a famous thought experiment, 16th-century philosopher 
René Descartes pointed out that even if all our physical sensations
were just a hallucinatory dream, our mind and thoughts 
would still be there. That, for him, was the ultimate proof
of our existence. And it led him to conclude that the conscious mind is something separate
from the material body that forms the core of our identity. The notion of a non-physical consciousness echoes the belief of many religions
in an immaterial soul for which the body is only 
a temporary shell. If we accept this, 
another problem emerges. How can a non-physical mind have
any interaction with the physical body? If the mind has no shape, 
weight, or motion, how can it move your muscles? Or if we assume it can, why can your mind
only move your body and not others? Some thinkers have found creative ways
to get around this dilemma. For example, the French priest 
and philosopher Nicolas Malebranche claimed that when we think about
reaching for a fork, it's actually god who moves our hand. Another priest philosopher 
named George Berkeley concluded that the material world
is an illusion, existing only as mental perceptions. This question of mind versus body
isn't just the domain of philosophers. With the development of psychology
and neuroscience, scientists have weighed in, as well. Many modern scientists reject the idea that there's any distinction 
between the mind and body. Neuroscience suggests that our bodies,
along with their physical senses, are deeply integrated 
with the activity in our brains to form what we call consciousness. From the day we're born, our mental development is formed
through our body's interaction with the external world. Every sight, sound, and touch create

for regulating our experience of self. And we have other senses,

no one's yet dreamt up?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If we accept that the body is deeply integrated in the brain, which of the following is not true?
Options: A. The experience of self can still be present independently from physical sensations, B. In the future, using neural prosthetics and new wearable devices may cause the human brain to restructure itself and develop new sensory representations, C. Mind-uploading might not be possible, unless we simulate a body with it to deliver physical sensations, D. Our consciousness is the result of our bodily interaction with the external world and therefore it cannot be separated from the body
Correct Option: A

**Transcript**:
Look at your hand. How do you know it's really yours? It seems obvious, unless you've
experienced the rubber hand illusion. In this experiment, a dummy hand is placed
in front of you and your real hand is hidden
behind a screen. Both are simultaneously stroked
with a paint brush. No matter how much you remind yourself
the dummy hand isn't yours, you eventually start to feel like it is, and inevitably flinch
when it's threatened with a knife. That may just be a temporary trick,
but it speaks to a larger truth: our bodies, the physical, 
biological parts of us, and our minds, the thinking,
conscious aspects, have a complicated, tangled relationship. Which one primarily defines you
or your self? Are you a physical body that only
experiences thoughts and emotions as a result of biochemical interactions
in the brain? That would be a body with a mind. Or is there some non-physical part of you
that's pulling the strings but could live outside 
of your biological body? That would be a mind with a body. That takes us to an old question of whether the body 
and mind are two separate things. In a famous thought experiment, 16th-century philosopher 
René Descartes pointed out that even if all our physical sensations
were just a hallucinatory dream, our mind and thoughts 
would still be there. That, for him, was the ultimate proof
of our existence. And it led him to conclude that the conscious mind is something separate
from the material body that forms the core of our identity. The notion of a non-physical consciousness echoes the belief of many religions
in an immaterial soul for which the body is only 
a temporary shell. If we accept this, 
another problem emerges. How can a non-physical mind have
any interaction with the physical body? If the mind has no shape, 
weight, or motion, how can it move your muscles? Or if we assume it can, why can your mind
only move your body and not others? Some thinkers have found creative ways
to get around this dilemma. For example, the French priest 
and philosopher Nicolas Malebranche claimed that when we think about
reaching for a fork, it's actually god who moves our hand. Another priest philosopher 
named George Berkeley concluded that the material world
is an illusion, existing only as mental perceptions. This question of mind versus body
isn't just the domain of philosophers. With the development of psychology
and neuroscience, scientists have weighed in, as well. Many modern scientists reject the idea that there's any distinction 
between the mind and body. Neuroscience suggests that our bodies,
along with their physical senses, are deeply integrated 
with the activity in our brains to form what we call consciousness. From the day we're born, our mental development is formed
through our body's interaction with the external world. Every sight, sound, and touch create
new maps and representations in the brain that eventually become responsible
for regulating our experience of self. And we have other senses,
besides the typical five, such as the sense of balance and a sense of the relative location
of our body parts. The rubber hand illusion,
and similar virtual reality experiments, show that our senses can easily
mislead us in our judgment of self. They also suggest that our bodies
and external sensations are inseparable from 
our subjective consciousness. If this is true, then perhaps Descartes'

in a silent room, the feeling of having a body
isn't something we can just imagine away. This question of mind and body

a physical body as Descartes suggested? Or a complex organism 
that's gained consciousness over millions of years of evolution thanks to a bigger brain and
more neurons than our distant ancestors? Or something else entirely that
no one's yet dreamt up?
